introduction.p: Many important sequences are generated by addition. In Example, we see an example of a sequence that is connected to a sum.

example.p: Suppose warfarin is taken by a particular patient in a 5 mg dose each day. The drug is absorbed by the body and some is excreted from the system between doses. Assume that at the end of a 24 hour period, 8 of the drug remains in the body. Let Q(n) be the amount (in mg) of warfarin in the body before the (n+1)st dose of the drug is administered.

li.p: Explain why Q(1) = 5 \times 0.08 mg.

Explain why Q(2) = (5+Q(1)) \times 0.08 mg. Then show that
Q(2) = (5 \times 0.08)\left(1+0.08\right) \text{mg} .

Explain why Q(3) = (5+Q(2)) \times 0.08 mg. Then show that
Q(3) = (5 \times 0.08)\left(1+0.08+0.08^2\right) \text{mg} .

Explain why Q(4) = (5+Q(3)) \times 0.08 mg. Then show that
Q(4) = (5 \times 0.08)\left(1+0.08+0.08^2+0.08^3\right) \text{mg} .
There is a pattern that you should see emerging. Use this pattern to find a formula for Q(n), where n is an arbitrary positive integer.

subsection.title: Geometric Series
subsection.p:
In Example we encountered the sum
(5 \times 0.08)\left(1+0.08+0.08^2+0.08^3+ \cdots + 0.08^{n-1}\right)

statement.p:
Let a and r be real numbers (with r \ne 1) and let
S_n = a+ar+ar^2 + \cdots + ar^{n-1} .
In this example we will find a shortcut formula for S_n that does not involve a sum of n terms.

li.p: Multiply S_n by r. What does the resulting sum look like?

Subtract rS_n from S_n and explain why
S_n - rS_n = a - ar^n .
Solve equation for S_n to find a simple formula for S_n that does not involve adding n terms.
Distribute the factor of r.
Look for common terms in the two expressions being subtracted.
Observe that you can remove a factor of S_n from S_n - rS_n.
rS_n = ar+ar^2+ar^3 + \cdots + ar^n .
S_n - rS_n = a - ar^n.
S_n = a\frac{1-r^n}{1-r}.

Note that
rS_n = ar+ar^2+ar^3 + \cdots + ar^n .

When we subtract rS_n from S_n the middle terms all cancel and we are left with
S_n - rS_n \amp = \left(a+ar+ar^2 + \cdots + ar^{n-1}\right) \amp\phantom{={}}{}- \left(ar+ar^2+ar^3 + \cdots + ar^n\right) \amp =a + (ar-ar) + \left(ar^2-ar^2\right) + \cdots + \left(ar^{n-1}-ar^{n-1}\right) - ar^n \amp = a - ar^n .

Factoring S_n from left hand side and dividing gives us a formula for S_n:
S_n(1-r) \amp = a - ar^n S_n \amp = a\frac{1-r^n}{1-r} .

subsection.p: The sum of the terms of a sequence is called a series. We summarize the result of Example in the following way.

assemblage.p:
A finite geometric series S_n is a sum of the form
S_n = a + ar + ar^2 + \cdots + ar^{n-1} , where a and r are real numbers such that r \ne 1. The finite geometric series S_n can be written more simply as
S_n = a+ar+ar^2+ \cdots + ar^{n-1} = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} .

subsection.p:
We now apply Equation to the example involving Warfarin from Example. Recall that
Q(n)=(5 \times 0.08)\left(1+0.08+0.08^2+0.08^3+ \cdots + 0.08^{n-1}\right) \text{mg} , so Q(n) is a geometric series with a=5 \times 0.08 = 0.4 and r = 0.08. Thus,
Q(n) = 0.4\left(\frac{1-0.08^n}{1-0.08}\right) = \frac{1}{2.3} \left(1-0.08^n\right) .

Notice that as n goes to infinity, the value of 0.08^n goes to 0. So,
\lim_{n \to \infty} Q(n) = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{2.3} \left(1-0.08^n\right) = \frac{1}{2.3} \approx 0.435 .
Therefore, the long-term level of Warfarin in the blood under these conditions is \frac{1}{2.3}, which is approximately 0.435 mg.

To determine the long-term effect of Warfarin, we considered a finite geometric series of n terms, and then considered what happened as n was allowed to grow without bound. In this sense, we were actually interested in an infinite geometric series (the result of letting n go to infinity in the finite sum). geometric series seriesgeometric

statement.p:
An infinite geometric series is an infinite sum of the form
a + ar + ar^2 + \cdots = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} ar^n .

subsection.p:
The value of r in the geometric series is called the common ratio geometric seriescommon ratio of the series because the ratio of the (n+1)st term, ar^n, to the nth term, ar^{n-1}, is always r:
\frac{ar^n}{ar^{n-1}} = r .

Geometric series are common in mathematics and arise naturally in many different situations. As a familiar example, suppose we want to write the number with repeating decimal expansion
N=0.1212\overline{12}
as a rational number. Observe that
N \amp = 0.12 + 0.0012 + 0.000012 + \cdots \amp = \left(\frac{12}{100}\right) + \left(\frac{12}{100}\right)\left(\frac{1}{100}\right) + \left(\frac{12}{100}\right)\left(\frac{1}{100}\right)^2 + \cdots . This is an infinite geometric series with a=\frac{12}{100} and r = \frac{1}{100}.
By using the formula for the value of a finite geometric sum, we can also develop a formula for the value of an infinite geometric series. We explore this idea in the following example.

statement.p:
Let r \ne 1 and a be real numbers and let
S = a+ar+ar^2 + \cdots ar^{n-1} + \cdots
be an infinite geometric series. For each positive integer n, let
S_n = a+ar+ar^2 + \cdots + ar^{n-1} .

Recall that
S_n = a\frac{1-r^n}{1-r} .
What should we allow n to approach in order to have S_n approach S?
What is the value of \lim_{n \to \infty} r^n for |r| \gt 1? for |r| \lt 1? Explain.
If |r| \lt 1, use the formula for S_n and your observations in (a) and (b) to explain why S is finite and find a resulting formula for S.

li.p: Let n increase without bound.
Think about what happens to powers of numbers that are less than or greater than 1.
Consider \frac{1-r^n}{1-r} and how the numerator tends to 1 as n \to \infty for certain values of r.

Observe that
S = \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n .
If r \gt 1, then \lim_{n \to \infty} r^n = \infty. If 0 \lt r \lt 1, then \lim_{n \to \infty} r^n = 0.

Since
S = \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n = \lim_{n \to \infty} a\frac{1-r^n}{1-r}
and
\lim_{n \to \infty} r^n = 0
for 0 \lt r \lt 1, we conclude that
S = \lim_{n \to \infty} a\frac{1-r^n}{1-r} = \frac{a}{1-r}
when 0 \lt r \lt 1.

Observe that
S = \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n .
If r \gt 1, then \lim_{n \to \infty} r^n = \infty. If 0 \lt r \lt 1, then \lim_{n \to \infty} r^n = 0.

Since
S = \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n = \lim_{n \to \infty} a\frac{1-r^n}{1-r}
and
\lim_{n \to \infty} r^n = 0
for 0 \lt r \lt 1, we conclude that
S = \lim_{n \to \infty} a\frac{1-r^n}{1-r} = \frac{a}{1-r}
when 0 \lt r \lt 1.

subsection.p:
We can now find the value of the geometric series
N = \left(\frac{12}{100}\right) + \left(\frac{12}{100}\right)\left(\frac{1}{100}\right) + \left(\frac{12}{100}\right)\left(\frac{1}{100}\right)^2 + \cdots . Using a = \frac{12}{100} and r = \frac{1}{100}, we see that
N = \frac{12}{100} \left(\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{100}}\right) = \frac{12}{100} \left(\frac{100}{99}\right) = \frac{4}{33} .

The sum of a finite number of terms of an infinite geometric series is often called a partial sum partial sum of the series. Thus,
S_n = a+ar+ar^2 + \cdots + ar^{n-1} = \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} ar^k . is called the nth partial sum of the series \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} ar^k. We summarize our recent work with geometric series as follows.

li.p:
An infinite geometric series is an infinite sum of the form
a + ar + ar^2 + \cdots = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} ar^n , where a and r are real numbers such that r \ne 0.

If |r| \lt 1, then using the fact that S_n = a\frac{1-r^n}{1-r}, it follows that the sum S of the infinite geometric series is
S = \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n = \lim_{n \to \infty} a\frac{1-r^n}{1-r} = \frac{a}{1-r}

statement.p: The formulas we have derived for an infinite geometric series and its partial sum have assumed we begin indexing the sums at n=0. If instead we have a sum that does not begin at n=0, we can factor out common terms and use the established formulas. This process is illustrated in this example.

li.p:
Consider the sum
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} (2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^k = (2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) + (2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^2 + (2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^3 + \cdots . Remove the common factor of (2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) from each term and hence find the sum of the series.

Next let a and r be real numbers with -1\lt r\lt 1. Consider the sum
\sum_{k=3}^{\infty} ar^k = ar^3+ar^4+ar^5 + \cdots . Remove the common factor of ar^3 from each term and find the sum of the series.

Finally, we consider the most general case. Let a and r be real numbers with -1\lt r\lt 1, let n be a positive integer, and consider the sum
\sum_{k=n}^{\infty} ar^k = ar^n+ar^{n+1}+ar^{n+2} + \cdots . Remove the common factor of ar^n from each term to find the sum of the series.
Think about how r = \frac{1}{3}.
Note that ar^3+ar^4+ar^5 + \cdots = ar^3(1 + r + r^2 + \cdots).
Compare your work in (b).
(2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \left[1 + \left(\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^2 + \cdots \right] .
ar^3+ar^4+ar^5 + \cdots = \frac{ar^3}{1-r}.
r^n+ar^{n+1}+ar^{n+2} + \cdots = \frac{ar^n}{1-r}.

Factoring out (2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) gives us
(2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \left[1 + \left(\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^2 + \cdots \right] \amp = (2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^k \amp = (2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \left(\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{3}}\right) \amp = (2)\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \left(\frac{3}{2}\right) \amp = 4 .

Factoring out ar^3 gives us
ar^3+ar^4+ar^5 + \cdots \amp = ar^3\left(1+r+r^2+ \cdots \right) \amp = ar^3\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} r^k \amp = ar^3 \left(\frac{1}{1-r}\right) \amp = \frac{ar^3}{1-r} .

Factoring out ar^n gives us
ar^n+ar^{n+1}+ar^{n+2} + \cdots \amp = ar^n\left(1+r+r^2+ \cdots \right) \amp = ar^n\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} r^k \amp = ar^n \left(\frac{1}{1-r}\right) \amp = \frac{ar^n}{1-r} .

An infinite geometric series is an infinite sum of the form
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} ar^k
where a and r are real numbers and r \neq 0.

The nth partial sum of the geometric series \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} ar^k is
S_n = \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} ar^k . A formula for the nth partial sum of a geometric series is
S_n = a \frac{1-r^n}{1-r} . If |r| \lt 1, the infinite geometric series \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} ar^k has the finite sum \frac{a}{1-r}.
